Name: pronamespace
Description: The OID of the namespace that contains this\n function

Name: prolang
Description: Implementation language or call interface of this\n function

Name: prosecdef
Description: Function is a security definer (i.e., a "setuid" function)

Name: proisstrict
Description: Function returns null if any call argument is null.\n In that case the function won't actually be called at all. Functions that are not "strict" must be prepared to handle null inputs.

Name: proretset
Description: Function returns a set (i.e., multiple values of the\n specified data type)

Name: provolatile
Description: provolatile tells\n whether the function's result depends only on its input arguments, or is affected by outside factors. It is i for "immutable" functions, which always deliver the same result for the same inputs. It is s for "stable" functions, whose results (for fixed inputs) do not change within a scan. It is v for "volatile" functions, whose results may change at any time. (Use v also for functions with side-effects, so that calls to them cannot get optimized away.)

Name: prorettype
Description: Data type of the return value

Name: proargtypes
Description: An array with the data types of the function\n arguments

Name: proargnames
Description: An array with the names of the function arguments.\n Arguments without a name are set to empty strings in the array. If none of the arguments have a name, this field may be null.

Name: prosrc
Description: This tells the function handler how to invoke the\n function. It might be the actual source code of the function for interpreted languages, a link symbol, a file name, or just about anything else, depending on the implementation language/call convention.

Name: probin
Description: Additional information about how to invoke the\n function. Again, the interpretation is language-specific.

Name: proacl
Description: Access privileges; see GRANT and REVOKE for details.
